data.text:
Paris seems to be destined to become the capital of France, no matter what happens. I personally say nothing is for certain in History.

What other French cities could potentially have become the capital of France? My money is on Orleans and Lyon as good candidates. What do you think?

How about a WI where Eleanor of Aquitaine has a son with Louis VII? Eleanor still is going to have problems with Louis, but they stay together (for the kids). Eleanor has control of the child, and raises young William (named after her father) in Aquitaine, far away from the cold city and lords of his father.

William rules from Poiters, and makes the city his primary headquarters in his wars against the Angevin Kings of England. The shift of capital to Poiters is continued by his heirs, for whom the Duchy of Aquitaine and the south of France is a much more important and wealthy support base than Paris and its environs.

Bordeaux has been a popular refuge for fleeing governments. Politically though, the capital would probably have been the capital of whatever region was the power base of the monarch, so Poitiers (although Bordeaux falls under that region as well), Toulouse or a city in Bourgogne would be the most likely candidate.

A capital in Marseilles might happen if the languedoc/languedouille conflict ended in favor of languedoc
